p.seg: Master Wenzhong’s teaching
is the continuation of the Way of theUncrowned King [i.e. Confucius];
therefore, the chapter “The KinglyWay” (Wangdao pian 王道篇) is placed at the head of this work.
Formersage kings of antiquity
observed attentively the movements of the TwoModes to make certain that [these movements] were in accord with thepower of heaven and earth;
therefore, the chapter “Heaven and Earth”(Tian di pian 天地篇) follows next.
When heaven is observed as thesuperior and earth the subordinate,
then [the relationship between] thesovereign and the vassal will be [properly] established;
therefore, thechapter “Service to the Sovereign” (Shijun pian 事君篇) follows next.
When serving the sovereign,
no one adhered more closely to heavenlypatterns than the Duke of Zhou;
therefore, the chapter “Duke of Zhou”(Zhou gong pian 周公篇) follows next.
The Way of Duke of Zhou
isnuminous because it adheres to The Book of Changes at its core;
therefore,the chapter “Queries about the Changes” (Wen Yi pian 問易篇) followsnext.
The Changes
is the fount of transformation,
but nothing ismore effective than the transformation of cultural practices by means ofrites and music;
therefore, the chapter “Rites and Music” (Li yue pian 禮樂篇) follows next.
Rites and music amplify culture while chroniclesrecord it;
therefore, the chapter “Delineating History” (Shushi pian 述史篇) follows next.
To promote refined culture and establish institutionalstandards,
there is nothing more effective than to elucidate the principlesof things.
Wei Xiang had accomplished exactly that;4
therefore, the chapter“Wei Xiang” (Wei Xiang pian 魏相篇) follows next.
When the yin andthe yang forces are harmonized,
then we will see clearly the innate patternsof things and the law of nature.
When we have investigated exhaustivelythe innate patterns of things and explored thoroughly the law ofnature, then we will arrive at an understanding of the concept ofmandates;5
therefore, the chapter “Determining Mandates” (Liming pian立命篇) follows next.
Without the Book of Changes, how can we everapprehend the law of nature and the workings of mandates?
Mr. Guan
isthe one who achieved the most profound understanding of the Changes;
therefore, the chapter “Guan Lang” (Guan Lang pian 關朗篇) followsnext to conclude this work.
When the Master gained Cheng, Qiu, Dong and Xue [as his students], hisSix [Continued] Classics became more luminous.
The compilation of theDuiwen (The Dialogues)
was the effort of these four students.
But first,Dong and Qiu died prematurely;
next, Cheng and Xue also passed away.
How could Master Wenzhong’s teaching flourish?
Alas,
we must nowawait the coming of a savant!
To discuss literary refinement without addressing internal integrity,
this means that culture (wen) no longer exists in the world.
How isthe Kingly Way going to prosper?
Master Wenzhong said:
A strong state conquers others with militaryforce.
A state possessing hegemonic power conquers others with wisestrategies.
A state possessing monarchial power conquers others with thedictates of what is appropriate.
A state possessing imperial power conquersothers with its moral influence.
To be sure, the imperial system has long ceased to exist but in name only.
A state possessing supreme powerconquers others by inaction.
he cannot possibly defeat the ways of monarchy andhegemony.
If the Son of Heaven employs military forceto conquer others,
On what basis then can he take the name emperor for himself?
Master Wenzhong said,
“It has been a long time since there was anemperor who conducted himself as an emperor should.”
Wang Xiaoyi asked,
“Why then do you still use the term ‘emperor’ inYuanjing [when you refer to the rulers of past dynasties]?”
The Master said,
“If you want to rectify names and validate actuality,
you cannot abandon using this term.
For those who functioned as emperorsin the past dynasties,
they did so in name only.”
The Master said,
“When the states of the Central Plains deviate from theproper way,
the neighboring barbarian tribes all know it.”
Wei Zheng said,
“Would you please elaborate on this?”
The Master said,
“‘When the Lesser Elegantiae falls into complete disuse,
all the neighboring barbarian tribes begin to cause disturbances onthe frontier.
This indicates that the states of the Central Plains had deviatedfrom the proper way.’5
Isn’t that the explanation?”
When Wei Zheng withdrew, he said to Xue Shou,
“I now know what isthe state of our time’s affairs.”
Zheng He slandered the Master in front of the Duke of Yue, saying,
“It washe [i.e., Wang Tong] who treated the Duke with disrespect.
Why does theDuke still hold him in esteem?”
The Duke of Yue sent someone to ask theMaster about this.
The Master said,

“If the Duke may be treated with disrespect,then I have acted correctly. If the Duke may not be treated withdisrespect, then I have erred. In either case, it reflects on me. Why doesthe Duke make it his business?” Thereupon, the Duke continued to treathim with the same regard as he did before.
Whenever the Master saw a farmer tilling, he always paid him respect byinquiring of his welfare.
Whenever he saw an official from court, healways paid him respect by bowing his head.
So long as he was within theboundary of a village or neighborhood,
Everymorning,
he washed and dressed himself as soon as the rooster crowed.
Shutian said:
Master Wenzhong’s teaching has risen
just as the Sui hascome to its final years
and the royal house is reaching its final end.
Forthose who are facing ruin,
I lament that he did not get to apply [his talentto save them].
For those who are about to prosper,
I regret that he did notget to see [it happen].
How assiduously he applied himself!
How soundhis words were!
How devoted he was to the welfare of the people!
When the Master was in Chang’an,
Yang Su, Su Kui and Li Delin all askedfor a meeting with him.
The Master went and talked to them.
When hereturned, he appeared distressed.
The disciples asked him the cause ofhis distress.
The Master said,
“When Yang Su talked to me,
he spent all day discussingstatecraft (zheng) without addressing the transformation of people(hua).
When Su Kui talked to me,
he spent all day discussing tonal qualities(sheng) without addressing correct measures (ya).
When Li Delintalked to me, he spent all day
discussing literary refinement (wen) withoutaddressing internal integrity (li).”
The disciples asked,
“Why should that distress you?”
The Master said,
“You don’t understand.
The three of them are all advisorsto the court on policy matters.
Now, to discuss statecraft withoutaddressing the transformation of people,
this means that ritual (li) nolonger exists in the world.
To discuss tonal qualities without addressingcorrect measures,
this means that music (yue) no longer exists in theworld.
That is why I am distressed.”
The disciples withdrew. The Master took out his zither and played thesong suite “Mighty” [from the Book of Songs].
The disciples were allmoved to tears by his music.
The Duke of Yue asked about government.
The master said:
“Be respectfuland frugal.”
The Duke of Pi asked about government.
The Master said:
“Bepure and fair.”
The Duke of Anping asked about government.
The Mastersaid:
“Do not be bellicose for the sake of fame.”
The Master said:
[Yao] Yi is pure and decorous.
{[Li] Jing is clement butdecisive.}
[Dou] Wei is congenial and learned.
[Xue] Shou is untrammeledin deportment but serious in mind.
[Jia] Qiong is perspicaciousand resolute.
[Du] Yan is honest and uncompromising.
{[Fang] Xuanlingis astute but circumspect.42
[Wei] Zheng is forthright but compliant.}
[Wen] Daya is forbearing and magnanimous.
[Chen] Shuda has attainedsimplicity and equilibrium.
If they meet the opportune time,
they willrise to ranks no lower than chief ministers and grand councilors.
Even so,they have not yet perfected their knowledge on rites and music.
Wen Daya asked: “What must a person be like before he can be trusted togovern others?”
The Master said:
“He must act by the principle of humaneness,
live bythe principle of tolerance,
and he must have a deep understanding of theintent of rites and music.”
[Wen Daya] asked: “May I ask what kind of a person would rank next?”
The Master said:
“He must be true in words
and considerate in action.
He must not be moved even when he is tempted with benefit or threatenedwith harm.”
[Wen Daya] asked again:
The Master said:
“He must be respectful but unyielding,
incorruptiblebut mindful.
He must be circumspect in order to preserve himself.
Butsuch a person is not good enough to rise above others.”
The Master said:
“Any person doing less than this
would be no different than a thief.
If must be, he might beenrolled among the reserve staff, perhaps.”
Howcan he be trusted with government affairs?
The deviation of historical writing [from its proper function]
began with[Sima] Qian and [Ban] Gu.
What they recorded was elaborate; but, of alltheir intents and purposes, it was inadequate.
The misrepresentation ofthe Spring and Autumn Annals
began with [Liu] Xin [46 BC–AD 23] and[Liu] Xiang [ca. 79–8 BC].
They disregarded the original text and reliedonly on its commentaries.
“May I ask why the Continued Songs encompasses theentire repertoire of the Six Dynasties era?”
The Master said:
“I presumethat you ask because Zhongni’s [i.e. Confucius’s] Three Hundred Songs[i.e., Book of Songs] begins and ends with the Zhou era.”
Xue Shou said:
“Yes.”
The Master said:
“How dare I ever expect to be Zhongni’s equal?
Yetat such a time of vicissitudes,
I have to keep looking up to him.
That iswhy I begin and end [the Continued Songs] with the Six Dynasties era.
It is for the sake of instructing [the generation of our time].
Heaven and Earth may have created me,
but they cannot nurture me.
Myparents may have nurtured me,
but they cannot help me to achieve perfection.
The one who helped me to achieve perfection is the Master [i.e.,Confucius].
[The power of] the Way is not only manifested in [the benevolenceI owe to] Heaven and Earth or my parents.
I, Tong, am beholden tothe Master for the benevolence
that he bestowed on me as much as I amto my own parents.
Are you, my lad, confusing the proper relationships ofhumankind?
How difficult it is indeed
to carry out the Kingly Way!
For six generationsof men in my family, tracing all the way down to the Magistrate of TongchuanDistrict,23
not a single one of them was not deeply committed tothis cause,
yet none was given the opportunity to effect the implementation[of the Kingly Way].
When they retired, they turned to writing
so asto record their ideas.
The work by the Master [Wang Tong’s ancestor sixgenerations removed]24
is called Disquisition on Changes of Time, composedof six chapters;
it is thorough in its discussion of the principle oftransformation and evolution of customs.
The work by the late Lord ofJiangzhou [Wang Tong’s ancestor five generations removed]
is called CollectedPapers Elucidating the Five Classics, composed of five chapters;
it is comprehensive in its discussion of the significance of works by sages andworthies.
The work by Lord Mu of Jinyang [Wang Tong’s great greatgrandfather]
is called Disquisition on the Fundamentals of Government,
it is illuminating in its discussion of the wayof emperors and monarchs.
The work by the late Lord of Tongzhou [WangTong’s great-grandfather]
is called Disquisition on the Trivial Matters ofGovernment, composed of eight chapters;
it is exhaustive in its discussionof the enterprise of monarchy and hegemony.
The work by Lord Xian ofAnkang [Wang Tong’s grandfather]
is called Candid Discussions of theRoyal Perfection, composed of nine chapters;
it is profound in its discussionof the correlations in the movements of the Three FundamentalPowers [i.e., Heaven, Earth and Man].
The work by the late Lord of Tongchuan[Wang Tong’s father]
is called A Brief Discussion of the Rise and Fallof Empires, composed of seven chapters;
it is lucid in its discussion of thesuccesses and failures of the six dynasties.
I, the insignificant one, had the fortune to behold the instructions that my ancestors left behind.
I diligently applied myself for nine years,
internalizing the tenets of my ancestors
and discerning the ideas of Zhongni[i.e., Confucius].
How clear it is now the relationship between Heaven and Man and the Way of Emperors and Kings!
When I was compiling the Primal Classic,
I examined historians’ discussions[of former dynasties].
But I found none of them sufficiently adequate for me to consult,
so I drew from [my grandfather’s] CandidDiscussions of the Royal Perfection.
When I was compiling the ContinuedSongs,
I surveyed collections [of songs and poetry].
But I found none of them sufficiently adequate for me to consult,
so I drew from [my distantancestor’s] Disquisition on Changes of Time.
When I was compiling theContinued Documents,
I scrutinized records [of speeches and promulgations].But I found none of them adequate for me to consult,
so I drew from [my great great-grandfather’s] Disquisition on the Fundamentals of Government.
During the time of [the Northern] Zhou [557–581] and [the Northern] Qi[550–577],
noblemen and ministers made no effort to attend to the preservation of ritual.
Xiangong said:
“When the Son of Heaven abandons ritual,
feudal lords should preserve it in their states.
When feudal lordsabandon ritual,
grandees should preserve it at home.”
It was the intent of Xiangong that treatises on ritual and music be written.
When the Master was in Jiang Commandery,
a man by the name ChengYuan came with Xue Shou [to visit him].
The Master discussed the SixClassics with him.
Upon taking his leave, Cheng Yuan said to Xue Shou:
“Your master is creating the template for distinguishing the proper relationsbetween Heaven, Earth, and Man,
so as to provide a guide for [rulersto achieve] Royal Perfection.
Were it not for your teacher,
we wouldclearly all be lost and deviating from the proper Way, wouldn’t we?”
Once Xue Shou was traveling in Guantao [in modern Hebei province],
and perchance he returned [to Longmen] in company with Wei Zheng.
Xue Shou told the Master:
“Zheng is of the caliber of Yan [Hui] and Ran[Geng].”45
Wei Zheng took up lodging at the Master’s home.
The Masterdiscussed the Six Classics with him.
For more than a month, Wei Zhengdid not set foot outdoor. U
pon taking his leave, he said to Xue Shou:
“Withno perspicacious ruler emerging, your master has arisen. Indeed, theThree Fundamental Powers and the Nine Divisions now rest in the careof a man of no official status.”
If one were to take Yao Yi’s eloquence,
Li Jing’s wisdom,
Jia Qiong and Wei Zheng’s uprightness,
Xue Shou’s compassion,
Cheng Yuan and Wang Xiaoyi’s cultivated refinement,
then reinforce these virtues with steadfastness
and regulate his personal conduct with ritual and music,
he would become a consummate person.
In the thirteenth year of the Daye reign period,
troubles arose in Jiangdu.
Around that time, the Master contracted an illness. …
His disciples, numbering severalhundred, convened to discuss [arrangements for postmortem rites].
Theysaid: “Our teacher is a Perfected Person, isn’t he?
There has never beenanyone like him since Confucius.
According to ritual,
a male is given acourtesy name at birth
so as to illustrate the innate potency that heembodies;
he is given a posthumous appellation upon death
so as toreplace his formal name [i.e., to accord him with honor and respect].
During the Master’s life, the world encountered a time of turmoil,
and noone followed the proper way.
He therefore extended the Book of Songsand the Book of Documents,
rectified rites and music,
compiled the PrimalClassic,
and explicated the fundamental principles of the Book ofChanges.
His works covered all aspects of the great doctrine of the sagesand all the situations that can happen in the world.
With Zhongni [Confucius]long gone,
has Culture not been invested here in him?
As the Bookof Changes says:
‘[The image of a] yellow lower garment signals [thearrival of] primal good fortune.
It indicates Culture abiding within.’8
Thuswe propose that Master Wenzhong be his posthumous appellation.”
